div.l: And smote þe Miller on þe pelled skulle
Þat doun he goth and cried harrow y dye
Þis clerkis bette him wel and lette him lye
And greythen hem ⁊and toke hir hors anon̄
And eke þe mele and on her wey þey gon̄
And atte þe Mille yet þey toke her kake
Of half a busschel floure ful wel y bake
Þus is þe proude Miller wel y bete
And hath y lost þe gryndyng of þe whete
And payed for þe soper euerydel
Of alen ⁊and Iohn and bette him well
His wife is swyued and his doughter als
Lo such it is a Miller to byn̄ fals
And þer for þis ꝓprouerbe is seyd ful soth
Him dar not wene wel þat yvel doth
A gilour shal him selfe bigiled be
And god þat sitteth high in Magiste
Save al þis company grete and smale
Þus have y quyt þe Miller in my tale
Here endeth the Reues tale 

And
Here begynneth the prolage of þe Cookes tale
The Coke of london̄ while þe Reve spake
For Ioy him þought he claued him on his bake
Ha ha qduod he for cristes passioıı̄un
This Miller hedde a sharp conclusioıı̄un
Vpon̄ his Argument of herbergage
Wel seide salamon in his language
Ne brynge nought every man in to þyn hous
For herberwynge by nyght is ꝑperelous
Wel ought a man avysed for to be
Whom þat he brought into his pryvete
I prey to god so eve sorow and care
If euer sith y hithte hogge of ware
Herde y a miller better y sette of a clerke
He hed a iape of malice in þe derke
But god forbede þat we stynten here
And þerfore yif ye vouchesaf to heere
A tale of me þat am a pore man̄
I wolle you telle as wel as I kan̄
A litel Iape þat fille in oure Citee
